title:
From terrestrial weather to space weather through the history of
  scintillation
authors: Emily F. Kerrison, Ron D. Ekers, John Morgan, Rajan Chhetri
abstract:
Recent observations of interplanetary scintillation (IPS) at radio
frequencies have proved to be a powerful tool for probing the solar environment
from the ground. But how far back does this tradition really extend? Our survey
of the literature to date has revealed a long history of scintillating
observations, beginning with the oral traditions of Indigenous peoples from
around the globe, encompassing the works of the Ancient Greeks and Renaissance
scholars, and continuing right through into modern optics, astronomy and space
science. We outline here the major steps that humanity has taken along this
journey, using scintillation as a tool for predicting first terrestrial, and
then space weather without ever having to leave the ground.
